awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of an Underwater Mobile Testbed Using a Software-Defined Networking Architecture
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, developing one of the first Software Defined Network (SDN)-based underwater mobile testbeds to support the operation of marine robot fleets, aims to address a technological bottleneck, that of achieving integrated communications and navigation underwater. A fleet of Autonomous Surface Vehicles (ASV)s are directed to follow sampling Autonomous Underwater Vehicles (AUVs) to provide acoustic and Magnetic Induction (MI) communication over relatively short ranges. Launching the following effort thrusts: Acoustic & MI Communication; Control of ASVs & UAVs; SDN architecture; and Integration and evaluation.

The testbed will be designed to achieve cost-effectiveness, transferability, flexibility, and scalability and is expected to become a stable instrument that is accessible by multiple research communities that include ocean acoustics, communication and networking, robotics, oceanography and environmental sciences. The hybrid acoustic/MI communication will be used to achieve reliability and high data rates across the mobile network for ASVs and AUVs, while smooth autonomy of the fleet would be ensured by cooperative localization and real-time data transfer among the ASV-AUV pairs. The testbed is expected to enable various research directions, including underwater swarming, deep-learning-based underwater joint networking and navigation, and integrated oil spill responses.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The oceans and the Great Lakes cover more than 70% of the Earth?s surface and are the basis for life. Autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs) are a powerful tool to sample the ocean and the Great Lakes. This NSF MRI project addresses the urgency to effectively transfer data in real-time among a fleet of navigating AUVs. It develops an underwater mobile testbed to achieve integrated communications and navigation. The project team at the University of Alabama and Georgia Tech creates a mobile platform using a commercial AUV that is deployable in realistic aquatic environments. An acoustic modem is integrated with the vehicle, and networking functions are integrated with vehicle autonomy software. The testbed can function as a platform to carry out acoustic transmission and communication tests underwater. A lake test has been conducted with environmental, acoustic, and navigational data collected. The experimental data and related toolbox have been released to the first batch of community users.

The MRI testbed and its development have significant impacts in the research and research training domains. The testbed development efforts significantly build capacity for water-related research at the University of Alabama. It will enhance the research competitiveness of Alabama in engineering and environmental sciences. At the national level, the testbed promotes intense interdisciplinary interactions among scientists and engineers in acoustic communication, computing networks, marine robotics, and oceanography, stimulated by the shared use of the testbed from institutions across the nation.

We provide integrated educational experiences to middle/high school, undergraduate, and graduate students. Both graduate and undergraduate students in this project gained significant research experiences in the development, testing, and deployment process in an interdisciplinary learning environment. Capstone projects were developed by the PIs to offer undergraduate students hands-on experiences. A summer camp was organized to teach middle/high school students to assemble remotely-operated vehicles (ROVs). The young students gained a fundamental understanding of robotics concepts when building their ROVs. All these contributed to the workforce development for the future blue economy.


Last Modified: 02/04/2022
Modified by: Aijun Song

Images (1 of )
  • The testbed was used to collect environmental, navigational, and acoustic data in the lake of Tuscaloosa, AL on Oct 7, 2021.
    Aijun Song
    Creative Commons
    Aijun Song
    MRI testbed in a lake experiment
  • The MRI testbed is built on the EcoMapper AUV. An acoustic modem has been integrated. Graduate and undergraduate students have been trained to operate the vehicle.
    Aijun Song
    Creative Commons
    Aijun Song
    EcoMapper AUV
  • The MRI Georgia Tech team develops two types of mini-robots, surface and underwater robots, which have their customized communication devices.
    Scott Mayberry
    Creative Commons
    Aijun Song
    Mini-robots developed at Georgia Tech
  • An ROV summer camp was organized on July 13-15, 2021. The MRI team taught 13 middle/high students basics of electronics and robotics through fun activities. The young students assembled their remotely operated vehicles and participated in the competitions in a swimming pool.
    Aijun Song
    Creative Commons
    Aijun Song
    ROV camp for local middle/high school students
